description:
Murid gammaherpesvirus 4, also known as mouse gammaherpesvirus 68 (MHV-68), is a species of virus belonging to the Gammaherpesvirinae subfamily of the Herpesviridae family. It is a naturally occurring pathogen found in small rodents, particularly in murid species such as the field mouse (Apodemus) and the wood mouse (Rombomys).

MHV-68 is a double-stranded DNA virus with a genome size of approximately 118 kilobase pairs. It is classified as a member of the Rhadinovirus genus within the Gammaherpesvirinae subfamily, which includes other well-known human gammaherpesviruses such as Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV).

MHV-68 is capable of establishing latent infections in its natural rodent hosts, where the viral genome persists in specific cell types, such as B lymphocytes, without causing overt disease. However, under certain conditions, such as immunosuppression, the virus can reactivate and cause acute lytic infections, leading to the production of infectious viral particles.

Due to its genetic and biological similarities to human gammaherpesviruses, MHV-68 has been extensively studied as a model system to understand the pathogenesis, latency, and immune evasion mechanisms of these important human pathogens. The use of MHV-68 in laboratory research has provided valuable insights into the complex interactions between gammaherpesviruses and their hosts.
